abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the outcome of the
            project as satisfactory, sustainability as highly likely,
            and its institutional development impact as substantial,
            while both the Bank, and Borrower performances are
            satisfactory. Valuable lessons are drawn form the project.
            The need for a focused project design is addressed, in light
            of the complexity of this project, which was conducive to
            many implementation delays. Furthermore, it is emphasized,
            that a Performance Management Framework, be included in
            future project design, to provide an early, and continuous
            assessment, of not only the input assessment of the project,
            but on the outcomes of education quality improvements, and,
            on the relevance of vocational training as well. Above all,
            it should include evaluations to measure the effect of
            investments in capacity building, improved training
            facilities, and better-trained staff, in addition to the
            cost effectiveness of public sector training. Implementation
            procedures should be clearly defined, so as to be fully
            understood and accepted by local authorities, early on at
            project preparation; likewise, project management staff
            should be fully trained at the early stages, to properly
            apply administrative, and financial management procedures,
            and thus avoid the capacity building failure experimented in
            those areas, resulting from weak supervision missions.
